intro: Arceuthobium siskiyouense, commonly known as the Siskiyou dwarf broomrape, is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on its host for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is native to the western United States, particularly in California and Oregon. The plant produces small, white or pale yellow flowers and has a highly reduced structure with no true leaves or stems. It is a hemiparasite, meaning it can photosynthesize to a limited extent but primarily depends on its host for survival. Due to its specialized lifestyle, it plays a unique role in the ecological dynamics of its native habitats.
